description: From Middle English parde, from Old French, from Latin pardus, from Ancient Greek πάρδος (párdos), possibly of Iranian origin and related to other Sanskrit and Ancient Greek terms (see leopard).

examples: Ten Brace, and more, of Greyhounds, snowy fair,And tall as Stags, ran loose, and cours'd around his Chair,A Match for Pards in flight, in grappling, for the Bear

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Partner; fellow; Used as a friendly appellation
examples: He had long believed, in secret, that his old pard, Tom Terror, was the leader of the Thugs that infested the famous pass; he was confident of it now, and it would be safe to say that, as he rode along, his neck did not itch as formerly.
